property.name: yarn.webapp.api-service.enable
property.description: Enable services rest api on ResourceManager.

property.name: yarn.scheduler.fair.allocation.file
property.description: Path to allocation file. An allocation file is an XML manifest describing queues and their properties, in addition to certain policy defaults. This file must be in the XML format described in the next section. If a relative path is given, the file is searched for on the classpath (which typically includes the Hadoop conf directory). Defaults: fair-scheduler.xml.

property.name: yarn.scheduler.fair.preemption
property.description: Whether to use preemption. Defaults to false.

property.name: yarn.scheduler.minimum-allocation-mb
property.description: The minimum allocation for every container request at the RM in MBs. Memory requests lower than this will be set to the value of this property. Additionally, a node manager that is configured to have less memory than this value will be shut down by the resource manager. Default: 1024

property.name: yarn.scheduler.maximum-allocation-mb
property.description: The maximum allocation for every container request at the RM in MBs. Memory requests higher than this will throw an InvalidResourceRequestException. Default: 8192

property.name: yarn.scheduler.minimum-allocation-vcores
property.description: The minimum allocation for every container request at the RM in terms of virtual CPU cores. Requests lower than this will be set to the value of this property. Additionally, a node manager that is configured to have fewer virtual cores than this value will be shut down by the resource manager. Default: 1

property.name: yarn.scheduler.maximum-allocation-vcores
property.description: The maximum allocation for every container request at the RM in terms of virtual CPU cores. Requests higher than this will throw an InvalidResourceRequestException. Default: 4

property.name: yarn.scheduler.fair.user-as-default-queue
property.description: Whether to use the username associated with the allocation as the default queue name, in the event that a queue name is not specified. If this is set to “false” or unset, all jobs have a shared default queue, named “default”. Defaults to true. If a queue placement policy is given in the allocations file, this property is ignored.

property.name: yarn.scheduler.fair.allow-undeclared-pools
property.description: If this is true, new queues can be created at application submission time, whether because they are specified as the application’s queue by the submitter or because they are placed there by the user-as-default-queue property. If this is false, any time an app would be placed in a queue that is not specified in the allocations file, it is placed in the “default” queue instead. Defaults to true. If a queue placement policy is given in the allocations file, this property is ignored.

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.resource.detect-hardware-capabilities
property.description: Enable auto-detection of node capabilities such as memory and CPU. Default: false

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.resource.cpu-vcores
property.description: Number of vcores that can be allocated for containers. This is used by the RM scheduler when allocating resources for containers. This is not used to limit the number of CPUs used by YARN containers. If it is set to -1 and yarn.nodemanager.resource.detect-hardware-capabilities is true, it is automatically determined from the hardware in case of Windows and Linux. In other cases, number of vcores is 8 by default. Default: -1

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.resource.memory-mb
property.description: Amount of physical memory, in MB, that can be allocated for containers. If set to -1 and yarn.nodemanager.resource.detect-hardware-capabilities is true, it is automatically calculated(in case of Windows and Linux). In other cases, the default is 8192MB. Default: -1

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.vmem-pmem-ratio
property.description: Ratio between virtual memory to physical memory when setting memory limits for containers. Container allocations are expressed in terms of physical memory, and virtual memory usage is allowed to exceed this allocation by this ratio. Default: -1

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.log.retain-seconds
property.description: Time in seconds to retain user logs. Only applicable if log aggregation is disabled. Default: 10800

property.name: yarn.log-aggregation-enable
property.description: Whether to enable log aggregation. Log aggregation collects each container's logs and moves these logs onto a file-system, for e.g. HDFS, after the application completes. Users can configure the "yarn.nodemanager.remote-app-log-dir" and "yarn.nodemanager.remote-app-log-dir-suffix" properties to determine where these logs are moved to. Users can access the logs via the Application Timeline Server. Default: false

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.remote-app-log-dir
property.description: Where to aggregate logs to. Default: /tmp/logs

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.remote-app-log-dir-suffix
property.description: The remote log dir will be created at {yarn.nodemanager.remote-app-log-dir}/${user}/{thisParam}. Default: logs

property.name: yarn.log.server.url
property.description: URL for log aggregation server

property.name: yarn.log-aggregation.retain-seconds
property.description: How long to keep aggregation logs before deleting them. -1 disables. Be careful set this too small and you will spam the name node. Default: -1

property.name: yarn.log-aggregation.retain-check-interval-seconds
property.description: How long to wait between aggregated log retention checks. If set to 0 or a negative value then the value is computed as one-tenth of the aggregated log retention time. Be careful set this too small and you will spam the name node. Default: -1

property.name: yarn.webapp.ui2.enable
property.description: In the server side it indicates whether the new YARN-UI v2 is enabled or not. Defaults to false.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.http-cross-origin.enabled
property.description: Enables cross-origin support (CORS) for web services where cross-origin web response headers are needed. For example, javascript making a web services request to the timeline server.

property.name: yarn.resourcemanager.webapp.cross-origin.enabled
property.description: Enable CORS support for Resource Manager.

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.webapp.cross-origin.enabled
property.description: Enable CORS support for Node Manager.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.hostname
property.description: The hostname of the Timeline service web application. Defaults to 0.0.0.0

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.enabled
property.description: Indicate to clients whether Timeline service is enabled or not. If enabled, the TimelineClient library used by applications will post entities and events to the Timeline server. Defaults to false.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.version
property.description: Indicate what is the current version of the running timeline service. For example, if “yarn.timeline-service.version” is 1.5, and “yarn.timeline-service.enabled” is true, it means the cluster will and must bring up the timeline service v.1.5 (and nothing else). On the client side, if the client uses the same version of timeline service, it must succeed. If the client chooses to use a smaller version in spite of this, then depending on how robust the compatibility story is between versions, the results may vary. Defaults to 1.0f.

property.name: yarn.system-metrics-publisher.enabled
property.description: The setting that controls whether yarn system metrics is published on the Timeline service or not by RM And NM. Defaults to false.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.schema.prefix
property.description: The schema prefix for hbase tables. Defaults to “prod.”.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.hostname
property.description: The hostname of the Timeline service web application. Defaults to 0.0.0.0

property.name: yarn.resourcemanager.system-metrics-publisher.enabled
property.description: Publish YARN information to Timeline Server

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.hbase.configuration.file
property.description: Optional URL to an hbase-site.xml configuration file to be used to connect to the timeline-service hbase cluster. If empty or not specified, then the HBase configuration will be loaded from the classpath. When specified the values in the specified configuration file will override those from the ones that are present on the classpath.

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.hbase.coprocessor.jar.hdfs.location
property.description: The default hdfs location for flowrun coprocessor jar.

property.name: yarn.nodemanager.aux-services
property.description: A comma separated list of services where service name should only contain a-zA-Z0-9_ and can not start with numbers

property.name: yarn.rm.system-metrics-publisher.emit-container-events
property.description: The setting that controls whether yarn container events are published to the timeline service or not by RM. This configuration setting is for ATS V2. Default: false

property.name: yarn.timeline-service.read.allowed.users
property.description: Comma separated list of user, followed by space, then comma separated list of groups. It will allow this list of users and groups to read the data and reject everyone else. Default value is set to none. If authorization is enabled, then this configuration is mandatory.

property.name: yarn.log.server.web-service.url
property.description: TimelineService v.2 supports serving aggregated logs of historical apps. To enable this, configure “yarn.log.server.web-service.url” to “${yarn.timeline-service.hostname}:8188/ws/v2/applicationlog”
